items.title: Aslan's sacrifice and resurrection as myth-made-concrete
items.detail: In Narnia, the eternal pattern of dying and rising finds fresh expression, stripping away the familiarity that often blinds us to wonder. Aslan's death upon the Stone Table is not allegory in the strict sense but rather the same divine story told as it might unfold in another world. The great Lion's willing sacrifice for Edmund reveals the heart of atonement without the theological terminology that can obscure its beauty. Children who might resist doctrinal explanation find themselves weeping over Aslan's death and rejoicing in his return—their hearts grasping truths their minds are not yet ready to analyze. The story does what arguments cannot: it awakens love.

items.title: Characters' transformation journeys as models of theosis
items.detail: Each child who enters Narnia undergoes transformation that mirrors the soul's journey toward God. Edmund moves from traitor to king through experiencing forgiveness; Lucy grows from fearful child to faithful friend through learning to trust; Eustace is literally un-dragoned, shedding his beastly nature through Aslan's painful grace. These are not mere character development but pictures of deification—creatures becoming more than they were through encounter with the divine. The children's growth into their royal nature parallels every Christian's calling to grow into their divine inheritance as sons and daughters of the Most High.

items.title: 'Deeper magic' as accessible metaphor for grace beyond law
items.detail:
The Stone Table's breaking becomes a perfect picture of how grace transcends justice without violating it. Children understand instinctively that there is something deeper than rules, something that fulfills law by going beyond it. The Deeper Magic from before the Dawn of Time captures in story what theologians struggle to express in systematic terms—that love is the foundation beneath justice, not its opposite. Through this narrative image, readers grasp that God's grace operates by principles more profound than human jurisprudence, principles that transform rather than merely excuse. The metaphor succeeds where abstract theology often fails.

items.title: Fantasy as preparation for receiving the True Myth
items.detail: Fairy tales and fantasy stories are not escapism but preparation, training the imagination to recognize truth when it appears in unexpected forms. The child who learns to love Aslan is being prepared to love Christ; the heart that thrills to tales of noble sacrifice is being tuned to appreciate the greatest sacrifice of all. Fantasy bypasses the critical defenses that often reject religious truth, allowing the gospel to enter through the imagination rather than the intellect. Like John the Baptist preparing the way, good stories prepare the soul to receive the True Story when it comes.

items.title: Imagination baptizing reason - 'sneaking past watchful dragons'
items.detail: The imaginative approach can steal past the watchful dragons of prejudice and preconception that guard the approaches to the heart. Where direct theological argument might be rejected, story slips in unnoticed, carrying its cargo of truth in the hold of delight. The reader's defenses are down because they think they are only reading a fairy tale, only to discover they have been ambushed by the gospel. Reason baptized by imagination becomes a more powerful tool for truth than reason alone, for it engages the whole person rather than merely the intellect. Stories reach the places that arguments cannot touch.

items.title: Cross-cultural resonance with archetypal patterns
items.detail: The deepest stories transcend cultural boundaries because they touch the universal patterns written on every human heart. The tale of innocent suffering for the guilty, of death defeated by love, of the high coming low to lift the lowly—these themes resonate across every culture because they echo the fundamental structure of reality itself. When we tell the Christian story well, it awakens recognition rather than requiring explanation. The myths of every people have been preparing them for this moment of recognition, like distant music suddenly heard clearly. Truth has a way of sounding familiar even when first encountered.

items.title: The Gospel as fulfillment of humanity's deepest story-longings
items.detail: Every culture tells stories of heroes who sacrifice themselves for others, of love conquering death, of the powerless triumphing over the mighty. These are not random inventions but echoes of the True Story that gives meaning to all other stories. The human heart knows what it longs for even when the mind cannot articulate it—we long for the happy ending that is both earned and given, for the victory that comes through surrender, for the love that proves stronger than death. The gospel satisfies these longings not by indulging them but by revealing their true object, showing us that the Story we have always been telling is actually true.
